awd_abstract_narration:
This research project will enrich and expand the Integrated Public Use Microdata Series (IPUMS). IPUMS is the world's largest population database, with information describing over one billion individuals drawn from 365 censuses and surveys taken in 94 countries. The extraordinary growth and redistribution of population and economic resources are reshaping the planet. To meet the challenges created by rapid demographic, economic, and environmental change, researchers must have full and open access to the best possible information. This project will expand the geographic and chronological coverage of the database, preserve it for future generations, and make the data available to users around the world. IPUMS data already have stimulated new research that transcends national boundaries and static interpretation. The data are broadly used by national and international agencies to inform policy. This project will enhance scientific understanding of critical policy-related issues such as population aging, international migration, climate change, and the effects of government programs on economic development and well-being. The project will promote teaching, training, and learning through three mechanisms. IPUMS will provide online data analysis and promote the sharing of curricular materials. Training workshops will be conducted, and the research team will further develop online training modules on how to use the data. The project will continue to employ a diverse group of graduate and undergraduate research assistants, including members of underrepresented groups, who will develop valuable skills in an interdisciplinary environment.

This research project will conduct five major activities. First, the research team will obtain and preserve the newest data as soon as they become available and seek out data from the 1960s through the 1980s that are at risk of destruction. Second, the research team will clean and process the data, drawing samples, correcting errors, applying confidentiality edits, and coding the data consistently across countries. Third, comprehensive documentation will be developed to guide users on the meaning of census and survey responses and their comparability across time and space. Fourth, the research team will maintain and improve the data access system. Fifth, education and dissemination activities will be expanded. IPUMS also will undertake activities designed to strengthen relationships with partner statistical agencies and promote long-run organizational sustainability. These activities will multiply the quality, quantity, accessibility, and interoperability of information about the changing human population, creating a transnational resource of unprecedented power for understanding human society on a global scale.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The International Integrated Microdata Series project supported the development of the world's largest collection of population data. The database, containing nearly 600 censuses and surveys from more than 100 countries, is available online to researchers. Unlike the published tables that are produced with every census, the International Integrated Microdata Series contains each person's individual responses to all the census questions, as well as the responses of everyone in their household. The project optimizes data for research use by ensuring standard formatting, consistent coding systems, rich documentation, and an easily accessible online data delivery system. This allows researchers to develop customized measures and to use the data for purposes that were not envisioned when the censuses were taken. Furthermore, most countries have contributed multiple years of census information, enabling comparative research across place and time. Because the data are so flexible, no names or other identifying information are included, to ensure privacy. More than 35,000 scholars and policy makers have accessed the data more than 185,000 times for research purposes. They have published more than 4,000 journal articles, monographs, and graduate theses.

 

During this grant period, from 2019 to 2024, the International Integrated Microdata Series processed and released to the research community 195 new censuses and labor force surveys from 37 countries. The project created new tools to enhance spatial analysis capabilities and facilitate other types of data interoperability. The project team created shapefiles to enable mapping results from the population data to national and subnational boundaries over multiple decades. Using custom-built geographic tools, migration and birthplace variables were made spatially consistent across time, enhancing opportunities for comparative research. User guides and sample code were developed to assist researchers in combining demographic data from the censuses with geographically referenced data from satellites and other sources describing temperature, rainfall, land cover, and more. We negotiated numerous data agreements with new countries and reached an ever-broadening group of global and interdisciplinary data users. Technological upgrades improved the data user experience and contributed to greater efficiency in data processing, metadata management, and web-based data dissemination.  

 

This International Integrated Microdata Series required collaboration with the national statistical offices of more than 100 countries, each of which have agreed to the public distribution of their data by an American institution, which is not the norm. Maintaining partnerships involves dozens of separate negotiations and the careful development of goodwill over many years. The project is the only public dissemination outlet for a large proportion of the data in the collection. The primary challenge was to make these data collected by so many contributors across multiple decades compatible across countries. We recoded the data to make them consistent and created extensive English-language documentation describing comparability issues. Censuses are not just counts of people, but contain a wealth of information on a host of topics, such as education, work, migration, fertility, housing, and disability. These data, describing over one billion persons, are now available to users everywhere at no cost. The International Integrated Microdata Series serves the scientific enterprise by reducing wasteful duplication of effort, eliminating common technical errors, making findings easier to replicate, and encouraging and facilitating sophisticated and powerful new analyses in many research domains. This constitutes an unprecedented resource for understanding the forces shaping the modern world over the past half century and into the future. All data obtained by the project are permanently archived, ensuring that this irreplaceable information will never be lost.
